newsitem.title: USA: Consumer prices move up 0.3 percent in September.
newsitem.headline: Consumer prices move up 0.3 percent in September.

text.p: Consumer prices rose moderately in September, the Labour Department said on Wednesday, continuing a pattern of relatively contained inflation despite the strength of the economy.
The department said the Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent last month, following an increase 0.1 percent in the prior month.
Excluding the usually volatile food and energy components, the department said, this "core" rate also rose 0.3 percent after rising 0.1 percent in August.
The September report matched Wall Street estimates of an increase of 0.3 percent for both the overall and core rate.
"When you look at the details, everything came in as expected," said Wadlo Best, senior economist at BZW Government Securities Inc. "All of these things were expected. There's really no surprise."
The new data on inflation follows last week's report showing wholesale prices advanced modestly in September.

The inflation numbers have been closely watched by the inflation-sensitive bond market and the high-flying stock market, which this week pushed over the 6,000 mark as measured by the Dow Jones Industrial Average for the first time in history.
Economists have become increasingly concerned that rising labour costs in a tightening job market could lead to a pickup in inflation in the months ahead.
But the CPI data suggested that so far businesses have been cautious about passing along higher labour costs in the form of large price increases.
"That 0.3 percent is an upside miss on the CPI and we're all right on the inflation front. These numbers are fine," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston Corp.
The department said food and beverage prices rose 0.5 percent while housing edged up 0.2 percent.
Energy prices were unchanged following a decline of 0.6 percent in August with gasoline (petrol) showing a decline of 0.4 percent.
New vehicle prices jumped 0.6 percent, posting the biggest rise since January 1991, when it was up an identical amount.
Apparel and its upkeep rose 0.5 percent after being down 1.4 percent in the prior month.
Airline fares rose 2.9 percent while overall transportation costs were up 0.5 percent.
Medical care cost continued their a pattern of modest increases, going up 0.2 percent, identical with August.
